text: In case you guys want a reference on other money apps out there: <http://www.producthunt.com/e/smart-money-apps>

attachments.title: Smart Money Apps - Manage and invest your cash like a boss by Product Hunt
attachments.text: A collection curated by Product Hunt, featuring products like $Cashtags by Square, Final, Robinhood for iOS, <http://Invoice.to|Invoice.to>, and Facebook Pay
attachments.fallback: Product Hunt: Smart Money Apps - Manage and invest your cash like a boss by Product Hunt

text: <!channel>: lindsay wants to go with the dual weight logo

<!channel> Hey guys, I just want to get your eyes on this deck. I haven't included any questions or anything yet, what should we be asking at this point? I don't want to open a can of worms by asking the wrong questions...

<https://www.dropbox.com/s/6v8bk3f7jnriueh/LG_App_Checkin_Preview_01A.pdf?dl=0>
looking
Also, Justin, can you tell me if there are any sections of copy in wireframes that I remove? Specifically the red note on GG wires.
one thing I see right off is that we need to change the section title at the end
it should be “Long Game Home"
without any of the additional copy
also - yes - we should cut the red copy on the GG wires
I'm confused about what should say Long Game Home
that's actually my main question — what is longgame home?
this is small - but in the interest of avoiding any confusion, in the 5th GG design screen can we make the value in the users wallet $40 instead of $45 to show that they’ve spent money on tickets
sorry - in the last screen in the wires
the one that shows the home screen of the app - the label to the right of it should read “Long Game Home” rather than “account setup"
note from me—i think the golden goose screens were sized a little too big within the phone. the edges on them seem to be slightly cropped
totally off-topic, but if I understood the onboarding wireframes, the user is asked to put in money after creating an account but before arriving to the actual normal experience. is that right?
yeah - they need to fund their account before they can do anything

setting aside how much work it might take, asking people to give money prior to enabling them to try the experience, is a tall order. i would advocate for an onboarding design that has real or fake credits or something to trigger the game dynamic motivation from actually playing the game.
otherwise the question becomes: what is the temptation to pay to get in?
so - I dont disagree at all
the main challenge is in the nature of the games
by law they basically have to be random drawings - so there really isn’t a “game” per se
it would be akin to buying a powerball ticket that was worth nothing
but I agree - it’s a very tall order

well in the context of functional MVP, i can see it being the plan. but as advice for onboarding for usability, it doesn't strike me as something we can stand behind. once built, it will prove the point.
believe me - it was a point of conversation with them
if this conversation has existed w/
ha
okay
i would expect less than 10% of people who registered to fund.
ignoring friends/family bias
truth be told, I think that may be the least of their worries
but yes - I agree
if they’re able to get this funded, I think they really need to do a deep dive on their user - which is currently not understood
but I think for what we need to cover off on for this stage - we’re good
May be worth mentioning / including as part of our phase 2 would be a bit of lightweight user testing to unpackage some of these issues.
im worried about phase 2 suffering from regression on phase 1 deliverables

anyway - i do think we can design to entice people to cross the line - but i would think most solutions would involve a simulation of a game experience. perhaps something that can be added iteratively, but the very best app designs, in my opinion, do not gate the main UX, and allow exploration so people can get comfortable with the pedigree of the place prior to registration and definitely prior to coughing up $.
agreed - at the same time, there isn’t a lot of UX precedent for what they’re trying to do
in spite of what they’re calling it - these aren’t “games"
theyre lottery tickets
yeah.
and moreover - they’re lottery tickets inside a savings account
well that's the actual reality
exactly
game play and relationship between person and screen can be separate from actual reality
which doesn’t discount what you’re saying
not to get myself back into a whole damn virtual economy convo, but for example, we could simulate the game play using a separate currency
but I think it’s a new enough paradigm that it deserves it’s own insight gathering and an IA/UX phase that falls outside a brand development phase
Im just trying to get them to a place where they can present the idea to investors
goosecoin
sho enough

some investors are as critical about experience. some of the more concrete data I got about onboarding before Uncorked was from VC people, directing their various member companies to conform to some of the ideals (Explorability/comfort for onboarding/conversion)
I totally agree
at the same time, I don’t think we had the time or budget to do the level of research or architecture to get to place where we could say “this is the right answer for on boarding"
maybe its a call out in our delivery.
client killed the idea of a secondary currency
given that, I’d rather give them something they’re comfortable talking about and hope they’re able to get people excited about the core concept
i brought that up in kick off
i also think our onboarding process aligns with exactly what we talked them through in our kickoff
they had a lot of feedback and direction for us.
my 2¢ is that we’ve given them our ux recommendations within their requested parameters and to a level of fidelity promised in this engagement
good
<@U02918BKW> - for the record, all of your concerns are issues i think we fleshed out in kick off
or at least the bulk of them

my take on Uncorked brand is that somewhere we follow up on the viability of user engagement. Marce's suggestion of testing is appealing, although by presenting a plan for followup, i do worry about the possibility that we point them away from the plan they agree to.
Polar/LukeW reference for onboarding i liked: <http://www.lukew.com/ff/entry.asp?1678>

attachments.text: LukeW Ideation + Design provides resources for mobile and Web product design and strategy including presentations, workshops, articles, books and more on usability, interaction design and visual design.
attachments.fallback: LukeW Ideation + Design provides resources for mobile and Web product design and strategy including presentations, workshops, articles, books and more on usability, interaction design and visual design.

text: that’s really nice
i think trent and justin came up with an experience similar to that which will work for long game
again, my take on the work that has been done thus far, i could be wrong

yeah, sorry, i just looked over the latest doc and just had my own moment. knowing that we're presenting to build this product, i want to empty our barrels of good advice before we pick up that scope. :wink:
My question about questions still stands. It's nearing 2 and I want to get this out asap. I'm ok leaving it as is unless anyone else thinks otherwise.
sorry
lets see
I suppose for me - Im okay leaving as is
i’m fine with it too
alternatively we can post it and follow up with questions later this afternoon
<@U06DFL7BP|charlesv> has joined the channel
